There have been a few fun answers in the
so I will direct you to them. Indeed, since JavaScript doesn't provide any guarantees, technically you can hijack
before React gets a chance to render it.

However, normally there is no way for a parent component to control the child output except by two mechanisms: passing props and providing context. You probably already know about props, and I won't talk about the context because it's an experimental API and has a few pitfalls. Don't use context in apps unless
Of course, if you get a DOM node for the component via refs, you can do anything you want with the DOM nodes of other components, but it will likely mess up React.
